title: Examples in Time Series Analysis and Application
text:
Preface
This is a R implementation of examples in “Time Series Analysis and Application” by Chi-Hyuck Jun.

Book: 시계열 분석 및 응용
Data download: 자유아카데미 자료실

title: 1  Smoothing
text:
1.1.1 Data
Create a data frame.

forest_fire <- tribble(
  ~year, ~cnt,
  2006, 369,
  2007, 418,
  2008, 389,
  2009, 570,
  2010, 282,
  2011, 277,
  2012, 197,
  2013, 296,
  2014, 492,
  2015, 623,
  2016, 391
)



1.1.2 Convert to time-series data
Convert the data frame to time series data frame (tsibble) object. You must set index with a column that represents timepoints for the series. Please note that tsibble automatically notice that the index is year and that the series is regular yearly series.

forest_fire_ts <-
  forest_fire |>
  as_tsibble(index = year)

forest_fire_ts

# A tsibble: 11 x 2 [1Y]
    year   cnt
   <dbl> <dbl>
 1  2006   369
 2  2007   418
 3  2008   389
 4  2009   570
 5  2010   282
 6  2011   277
 7  2012   197
 8  2013   296
 9  2014   492
10  2015   623
11  2016   391




1.1.3 Moving average
Compute moving average by calling slider::slide_mean(). Set complete = TRUE to return missing value NA when there are missing observations in the sliding window.

forest_fire_ma <-
  forest_fire_ts |>
  mutate(
    ma3 = slider::slide_mean(cnt, before = 2, after = 0, complete = TRUE),
    ma6 = slider::slide_mean(cnt, before = 5, after = 0, complete = TRUE)
  )

forest_fire_ma

# A tsibble: 11 x 4 [1Y]
    year   cnt   ma3   ma6
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
 1  2006   369   NA    NA 
 2  2007   418   NA    NA 
 3  2008   389  392    NA 
 4  2009   570  459    NA 
 5  2010   282  414.   NA 
 6  2011   277  376.  384.
 7  2012   197  252   356.
 8  2013   296  257.  335.
 9  2014   492  328.  352.
10  2015   623  470.  361.
11  2016   391  502   379.


Now, forest_fire_ma is a time series data frame with three series: original value cnt, 3-yr moving average ma3, and 6-yr moving average ma6.


1.1.4 Visualization
Covert this to a long form by calling pivot_longer(). The resulting time series data frame will have key that is a label of each series.

forest_fire_ma_long <- 
  forest_fire_ma |>
  pivot_longer(c(cnt, ma3, ma6), names_to = "statistics")

forest_fire_ma_long

# A tsibble: 33 x 3 [1Y]
# Key:       statistics [3]
    year statistics value
   <dbl> <chr>      <dbl>
 1  2006 cnt          369
 2  2006 ma3           NA
 3  2006 ma6           NA
 4  2007 cnt          418
 5  2007 ma3           NA
 6  2007 ma6           NA
 7  2008 cnt          389
 8  2008 ma3          392
 9  2008 ma6           NA
10  2009 cnt          570
# ℹ 23 more rows


Visualize time series data. Call autoplot() with measurement variable name to draws line plot by each key.

forest_fire_ma_long |> 
  autoplot(value)

Warning: Removed 7 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_line()`).

title: 1  Smoothing
text:
1.2 Example 1.2

1.2.1 Load data

household <- 
  read_excel("data/J01.xlsx", skip = 1) |> 
  rename(cnt = `#households`)



1.2.2 Convert to time-series data

household_ts <-
  household |> 
  as_tsibble(index = year)

household_ts

# A tsibble: 18 x 2 [1Y]
    year   cnt
   <dbl> <dbl>
 1  2000  2255
 2  2001  2438
 3  2002  2628
 4  2003  2818
 5  2004  3001
 6  2005  3186
 7  2006  3378
 8  2007  3571
 9  2008  3766
10  2009  3963
11  2010  4174
12  2011  4380
13  2012  4563
14  2013  4756
15  2014  4965
16  2015  5179
17  2016  5382
18  2017  5562




1.2.3 Train/test split

household_ts_train <-
  household_ts |> 
  filter(year <= 2014)

household_ts_test <-
  household_ts |> 
  filter(year > 2014)



1.2.4 Double moving average with N = 4

N <- 4

household_double_ma <-
  household_ts_train |> 
  mutate(
    ma = slider::slide_mean(cnt, before = N - 1, after = 0, complete = TRUE),
    ma_double = slider::slide_mean(ma, before = N - 1, after = 0, complete = TRUE)
  )

household_double_ma

# A tsibble: 15 x 4 [1Y]
    year   cnt    ma ma_double
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl>
 1  2000  2255   NA        NA 
 2  2001  2438   NA        NA 
 3  2002  2628   NA        NA 
 4  2003  2818 2535.       NA 
 5  2004  3001 2721.       NA 
 6  2005  3186 2908.       NA 
 7  2006  3378 3096.     2815 
 8  2007  3571 3284      3002.
 9  2008  3766 3475.     3191.
10  2009  3963 3670.     3381.
11  2010  4174 3868.     3574.
12  2011  4380 4071.     3771 
13  2012  4563 4270      3970.
14  2013  4756 4468.     4169.
15  2014  4965 4666      4369.


Visualize results.

household_double_ma |> 
  pivot_longer(c(cnt, ma, ma_double), names_to = "statistics") |> 
  autoplot(value)

Warning: Removed 9 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_line()`).











1.2.5 Estimate a slope
Take the latest moving average and double moving average.

latest <- 
  household_double_ma |> 
  slice_tail(n = 1)

latest

# A tsibble: 1 x 4 [1Y]
   year   cnt    ma ma_double
  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl>
1  2014  4965  4666     4369.


Compute a slope

b <- (latest$ma - latest$ma_double) / (N - 1) * 2
b

[1] 198.1667




1.2.6 Prediction

household_ts_test |> 
  mutate(
    ma = latest$ma,
    ma_double = 2 * latest$ma - latest$ma_double + (year - latest$year) * b
  )

# A tsibble: 3 x 4 [1Y]
   year   cnt    ma ma_double
  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl>
1  2015  5179  4666     5161.
2  2016  5382  4666     5360.
3  2017  5562  4666     5558.

title: 1  Smoothing
text:
1.3 Examples 1.3 - 1.4

1.3.1 Load data

patent <- 
  read_excel("data/J02.xlsx") |> 
  rename(cnt = `#patents`)



1.3.2 Convert to time-series data

patent_ts <-
  patent |> 
  as_tsibble(index = year)

patent_ts

# A tsibble: 24 x 2 [1Y]
    year   cnt
   <dbl> <dbl>
 1  1993  21.5
 2  1994  28.6
 3  1995  59.2
 4  1996  68.4
 5  1997  67.3
 6  1998  50.6
 7  1999  56  
 8  2000  72.8
 9  2001  73.7
10  2002  76.6
# ℹ 14 more rows




1.3.3 Train/test split

patent_ts_train <-
  patent_ts |> 
  filter(year <= 2013)

patent_ts_test <- 
  patent_ts |> 
  filter(year > 2013)



1.3.4 Example 1.3: Double exponential smoothing with \(\alpha = 0.2\)

1.3.4.1 Smoothing on training data

alpha <- 0.2

ets_step <- function(x, y, alpha) {
  stopifnot(alpha >= 0)
  stopifnot(alpha <= 1)
  (1 - alpha) * x + alpha * y
}

patent_ets <- 
  patent_ts_train |> 
  mutate(
    es = accumulate(cnt, ets_step, alpha = alpha),
    es_double = accumulate(es, ets_step, alpha = alpha)
  )

patent_ets

# A tsibble: 21 x 4 [1Y]
    year   cnt    es es_double
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl>
 1  1993  21.5  21.5      21.5
 2  1994  28.6  22.9      21.8
 3  1995  59.2  30.2      23.5
 4  1996  68.4  37.8      26.3
 5  1997  67.3  43.7      29.8
 6  1998  50.6  45.1      32.9
 7  1999  56    47.3      35.7
 8  2000  72.8  52.4      39.1
 9  2001  73.7  56.6      42.6
10  2002  76.6  60.6      46.2
# ℹ 11 more rows


Visualize the smoothing results.

patent_ets |> 
  pivot_longer(c(cnt, es, es_double), names_to = "statistics") |> 
  autoplot(value)










1.3.4.2 Estimate coefficients
Take the last training time point.

latest <- 
  patent_ets |> 
  slice_tail(n = 1)

n_train <- nrow(patent_ets)
latest_year <- latest$year

Estimate slope b.

b <- alpha / (1 - alpha) * (latest$es - latest$es_double)
b

[1] 5.851673


Estimate constant c.

c <- 2 * latest$es - latest$es_double - b * n_train
c

[1] 32.22202




1.3.4.3 Prediction

patent_ts_test |> 
  mutate(
    forecast = c + b * (n_train + (year - latest_year)),
    forecast_error = cnt - forecast
  )

# A tsibble: 3 x 4 [1Y]
   year   cnt forecast forecast_error
  <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>          <dbl>
1  2014  164.     161.          3.14 
2  2015  167.     167.          0.489
3  2016  163.     173.         -9.26 





1.3.5 Example 1.4: Holt linear

1.3.5.1 Smoothing on training data
Implement a function to update L and b in each iteration (i.e. each additional observation).

holt_step <- function(param, x, alpha, beta) {
  L <- param$L
  b <- param$b

  L_new = alpha * x + (1 - alpha) * (L + b)
  b_new = beta * (L_new - L) + (1 - beta) * b

  res <- list(L = L_new, b = b_new)

  res
}

Set parameters for Holt smoothing.

alpha <- 0.2
beta <- 0.2

Initialize L and b values.

L1 <- patent_ts_train$cnt[1]
b1 <- patent_ts_train$cnt[2] - patent_ts_train$cnt[1]

Compute Holt smoothing over training time periods.

patent_holt <- 
  patent_ts_train |> 
  mutate(
    es_double = accumulate(patent_ts_train$cnt[-1], holt_step, .init = list(L = L1, b = b1), alpha = alpha, beta = beta)
  ) |> 
  unnest_wider(es_double) |> 
  as_tsibble(index = year)







Note



unnest_wider() returns tibble object, not tsibble object. sCall as_tsibble() to convert the results back to tsibble object.


Visualize smoothing results.

patent_holt |> 
  pivot_longer(c(cnt, L), names_to = "statistics") |> 
  autoplot(value)










1.3.5.2 Prediction
Obtain the latest value of L and b.

latest <- 
  patent_holt |> 
  slice_tail(n = 1)

latest

# A tsibble: 1 x 4 [1Y]
   year   cnt     L     b
  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1  2013   160  157.  5.84


Make a prediction on test data with linear trend assumption.

patent_ts_test |> 
  mutate(
    forecast = latest$L + latest$b * (year - latest$year),
    forecast_error = cnt - forecast
  )

# A tsibble: 3 x 4 [1Y]
   year   cnt forecast forecast_error
  <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>          <dbl>
1  2014  164.     163.          0.955
2  2015  167.     169.         -1.68 
3  2016  163.     175.        -11.4
